title: 108_s1947
content: The Act may be cited as the "Preserving Independence of Financial Institution Examinations Act of 2003". It pertains to the offer and acceptance of credit. Title 18, United States Code, is amended by striking sections 212 and 213 and inserting a new section regarding the offer of loans or gratuities to financial institution examiners. It imposes fines and imprisonment for officers, directors, or employees of financial institutions who provide loans or gratuities to examiners. Federal regulatory agencies may establish additional limitations on credit applications and receipt. The section discusses the application and receipt of credit and residential mortgage loans under federal financial institution regulatory agencies. Definitions for terms like 'examiner' and 'Federal financial institution regulatory agency' are provided. The curr_chunk discusses various federal financial institution regulatory agencies, excluding certain entities from the definition of a financial institution. It also clarifies that a loan does not include a credit card account or a loan secured by residential real property under specific conditions. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for credit card accounts and residential real property loans, ensuring that terms and conditions are not more favorable to the examiner than to other borrowers in similar circumstances. For residential real property loans, the loan must be for the applicant's primary residence. The curr_chunk discusses the consequences for financial institution examiners who accept loans or gratuities from entities they examine, including fines, imprisonment, disqualification from office, and repayment of the loan. The terms and definitions related to this regulation are also clarified. The table of sections in chapter 11 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include new sections 212 and 213 regarding offering and accepting loans or gratuities by financial institution examiners. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
